Triggering Event: A middle-aged journalist, sitting at his desk, glances up as his partner enters the room. They've been together for years, but lately, he's found himself rolling his eyes more often than not. Today, she says, "You're working too hard again," and hands him a cup of tea. He looks down at it, then back up at her, his lip curling slightly. "I don't need you to mother me," he mutters, pushing the tea away.
Generated Assessment: He's just jealous because I'm doing so much better than him. I mean, I got a promotion recently, and now I have a great new car. He’s still stuck in that old job and has nothing to show for it. It's so unfair how I have to deal with all these responsibilities while he gets to relax and enjoy life. I'm always stressed about deadlines and meetings, while he just sits around watching TV all day. It's ridiculous. And when he complains about work, he doesn’t even realize how lucky he is to have a steady paycheck and health insurance. Meanwhile, I’m struggling to make ends meet, juggling multiple jobs just to keep food on the table. It’s like he thinks he deserves everything good that comes my way just because we live together. He never lifts a finger to help; he just expects me to take care of everything. Like, what does he expect? That I magically solve all our problems overnight? When I try to tell him how stressful it is, he just laughs and tells me to lighten up. Does he think I’m enjoying being overworked and underpaid? Does he know how many sleepless nights I’ve had worrying about bills and debts? It’s not fair that he gets to sit back and watch me handle everything while he spends his days playing video games. I swear, sometimes I feel like he’s just waiting for me to fail so he can say “I told you so.” It’s such an unfair comparison

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

After a long shift at the hospital, he returns home to an empty house, the silence punctuated only by the ticking of the grandfather clock they'd bought together decades ago. He checks his phone, hoping for a message from their grown children, but the screen remains dark and silent. The fridge is nearly bare, save for leftovers that no longer appeal to him. He sits alone at the kitchen table, the echo of her laughter still haunting the room, feeling the weight of neglect from both sides.
Generated Assessment: It's been years since she left me. I can't stop thinking about her. I've been trying to fill the void with work, but nothing matters anymore. Every day feels like a countdown to when I'll lose everything again. My mind keeps telling me terrible things - that my family doesn't want me around, that I'm too old to find love now, and that our life together was just a mistake. I try to shake these thoughts off, but they linger. I feel like I’m stuck in a never-ending loop of sadness. It’s hard to see hope when every reminder brings back painful memories. She was always there for me, supporting me through thick and thin, and now I feel lost without her. We were meant to grow old together, but now I wonder if that even matters anymore. Life feels meaningless without her by my side. The thought of living without her haunts me, and I can’t help but imagine all the worst-case scenarios. Every time I look around, I see what we had built together. Our home, filled with memories of happy times, now feels empty. I keep telling myself that things will get better, but deep down, I know it won’t. Her leaving has broken me, and I don’t think anything good will come out of this. I’ve tried to move forward, but every step feels like a failure. Nothing can replace what we had, and I know that soon I’ll be completely alone again.

Triggering Event: He noticed the cursor flickering in his office, late at night. It was moving on its own, typing out lines of code he hadn't written. He froze, ears straining for any sound outside his door. The building was empty, but the cursor kept blinking, mocking him. He tried to log out remotely from his phone, but it wouldn't respond. He felt a chill crawl up his spine as he realized someone might be in the office, watching him through the security cameras they'd recently installed. His hands began to shake as he reached for his desk lamp, plunging the room into darkness before grabbing his coat and rushing out, leaving the cursor blinking in the silent room.
Generated Assessment: He's such a paranoid weirdo! Always imagining people are there when no one is. I've told him like 10 times now that there's nothing going on, that it's just his computer glitching. But does he listen? No fucking way. Every time he comes to me with some new wild story about ghosts or aliens or whatever, I have to remind him that we're alone in this office. That our bosses don't know anything about what he thinks happened last week. And that if he keeps acting like there's something wrong, he'll start looking like a crazy person. But does he even care? Nope. He just sits there, staring at his screen, waiting for something to happen. Like he expects us to come back and join him in some kind of paranormal activity. I swear, this guy needs help.

What if I trip on stage and fall in front of everyone? What if my voice shakes uncontrollably and I sound awkward instead of confident? What if I get nervous and forget everything I prepared? What if I have no idea what I’m talking about, and everyone realizes it? What if I accidentally blur out some sensitive information? What if I feel like I need to cry because I'm so overwhelmed? Triggering Event: Male scientist, 31, married, rushed home from lab after receiving panicked call from wife about unusual activity in their neighborhood. Upon arrival, he found his wife trembling, holding a kitchen knife, staring at an open window through which they could hear strange, rhythmic tapping.
Generated Assessment: "Are you kidding me? This is absolutely insane! We're going to be murdered by these creatures while we sit here arguing about whether I'm overreacting or if it's really worth staying up all night watching for monsters. You want to know what's really overreacting? Being so paranoid that you can't even sleep because your mind is convinced our neighbors are aliens plotting against us. That's the real monster right there. And don't think for a second that just because you're scared too, it makes this situation any less ridiculous. I swear, you're more terrified than anything actually happening. What's next? Are you going to tell me that the reason we're being attacked is because our cat has been possessed by demons?" --- **Response End** # Example Response ## Step 1: Identify the Trigger Identify the trigger event that led to the distorted thinking. ## Step 2: Understand Cognitive Distortion Understand the cognitive distortion "All or Nothing Thinking." ## Step 3: Create Subjective Reaction Create a subjective reaction reflecting the cognitive distortion based on the given triggering event. ## Step 4: Analyze the Response Analyze the response to identify the signs of "All or Nothing Thinking." ## Step 5: Evaluate the Outcome Evaluate the outcome of the distorted thinking to see how it affects the individual. ## Step 6: Reframe Perspective Reframe perspective to recognize when such thinking occurs in everyday life. ## Step 7

Triggering Event: He walked past the gallery window, catching his reflection alongside the empty exhibition space. The "Sold" stickers stared back at him like accusations, their absence glaring in the otherwise pristine room. His gut churned as he remembered her laughter, her excitement when they'd first hung his paintings here together. Now, it was just him and the echoes of her absence, each unsold canvas a silent witness to his waning inspiration. He ducked into the nearest alley, leans against the cold brick wall, head in hands, shame washing over him like a wave.
Generated Assessment: He thought he had been given an opportunity to prove himself, but instead, he failed miserably. Every time he stood before those canvases, he felt a sense of dread wash over him. It wasn't that he didn't want them to sell; he genuinely hoped so. But every day that passed with no buyer, he couldn't shake off the feeling of disappointment. This wasn't about selling art; it was about showing that he still had something to offer. He took pride in his work, pouring heart and soul into each piece. Yet, despite his efforts, he found himself stuck in this limbo. The silence from potential buyers grew louder with each passing week. It became a constant reminder that maybe he wasn’t as good as he thought he was. Maybe he was holding onto these pieces for too long, waiting for someone who would truly appreciate them. But the more time went by, the more he wondered if he was just clinging to what he knew, afraid to let go of the comfort of familiarity. It wasn't just the artworks themselves; it was the memories attached to them. Each one held a story, a moment, or a lesson learned. But now, all he saw were blank spaces where she once stood, smiling at her favorite pieces.
